We're working on more stories right now
Inside the House leadership scramble.

                AP Photo

            By 
Lauren French
             and 
John Bresnahan

09/30/15 11:04 AM EDT

                    Updated 09/30/15 11:11 AM EDT
House Republicans will hold elections for new leaders on Oct 8.
During the closed-door elections, Republican lawmakers will back a candidate to replace retiring Speaker John Boehner and likely select a new slate of leaders. It is expected to be contentious with multiple candidates vying for each position as the conference struggles to regain its footing after the Ohio Republican’s surprise announcement last week.
Boehner said in a statement that the Republican Conference made it “clear” lawmakers want to move quickly to elect new leaders.
“After consulting with our conference, a large majority of our members have made clear they want these elections held next week,” Boehner said. “With their considerations in mind, the House leadership elections will take place on Thursday, Oct. 8.” 
Majority Leader Kevin McCarthy (R-Calif.) is expected to win the speaker's gavel. He’s running against Florida Republican Rep. Daniel Webster, who unsuccessfully tried to beat Boehner in the speaker election earlier this year.
If McCarthy wins, that opens the door for a majority leader election. Reps. Tom Price of Georgia and Steve Scalise of Louisiana, who is the current majority whip, both are vying for that post. 
If Scalise wins, there will also be a race for majority whip.
 © 2015 POLITICO LLC
description: House Republicans will hold elections for their leaders on October 8
title: Leadership elections scheduled for next week
